headline.main: Is a Patients' Rights Bill the Cure?

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''A Wrong Turn on Patients' Rights,'' by Marcia Angell (Op-Ed, June 23):

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Marcia Angell's solution to the managed-care disaster -- to extend a Medicare system to everyone -- is not the best (Op-Ed, June 23). She suggests that Medicare is a better alternative because it is fairer and more efficient. In fact, Medicare is an arbitrary system that is as restrictive as managed care. Medicare pioneered the practice of having clerks issue blanket denials of service.

headline.main: Is a Patients' Rights Bill the Cure?

docs.abstract: Dr David H Fields letter points out some shortcomings in Marcia Angell's solution (June 23 Op-Ed) to managed-care disaster--to extend Medicare system to everyone; contends Medicare is an arbitrary system that is as restrictive as managed care

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Marcia Angell (Op-Ed, June 23) is right when she predicts that either of the patients' rights bills under consideration would reduce access to insured health care and make it more costly for those still covered. The only positive outcome from the passage of either bill would be further deterioration of the current system to the point at which there is finally a public outcry to scrap it.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Supreme Court asked the Justice Department today for its views on laws that bar health care plans from setting up closed networks of doctors, pharmacies and other medical providers. The health insurance industry has been fighting so-called any-willing-provider laws, which are in place in various forms in 24 states. The laws generally require health plans with preferred provider networks to pay for coverage provided by any doctor who has accepted the plan's payment terms.

headline.main: Court May Review Health Insurance Case

docs.abstract: US Supreme Court asks Justice Department for its views on laws that bar health care plans from setting up closed networks of doctors, pharmacies and other medical providers; so-called any-willing-provider laws in place in various forms in 24 states generally require health plans with preferred provider networks to pay for coverage provided by any doctor who has accepted plan's payment terms; Kentucky's any-willing-provider law is being challenged by Aetna, Humana and other health-insurance companies (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate began a second week of debate today on a far-reaching bill to define patients' rights, with Democrats looking for some way to limit the liability of employers who might be sued by employees in disputes over health care benefits. The Democrats' bill would guarantee patients a wide range of rights and would make it easier for them to sue health maintenance organizations and other health plans in federal and state courts. President Bush has threatened to veto the bill, saying it would raise the cost of health insurance by exposing employers as well as insurers to new lawsuits.

headline.main: Shield Is Sought for Employers Under Patients' Bill of Rights

docs.lead_paragraph: New Yorkers complain more about their health maintenance organizations than any other consumer issue, according to an analysis of state records released yesterday by Senator Charles E. Schumer. The study found that in 1999, the State Department of Insurance closed 7,558 complaints. Automobile insurance complaints were second with 7,181. But Leslie Moran, a spokeswoman for the Health Plan Association, an H.M.O. group, said that Senator Schumer's analysis included 5,429 complaints from doctors about slow payment. Once these were removed, the tally was 2,129, she said.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: H.M.O. Complaints

docs.abstract: Analysis of New York State Department of Insurance complaints show residents are most vocal when it comes to HMO issues (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, New York State legislators gave themselves a raise after agreeing that their paychecks would be withheld whenever the state budget came in late. This was supposed to remedy their chronic inability to deliver a budget by the April 1 deadline. The scheme has not worked as planned. This year the budget is more than two months late with no resolution in sight. So the lawmakers, who are not getting paid anyway, are preparing to go home, thus bringing their work output into line with their pay intake. What this also means is that in addition to their failure to fashion a budget, the legislators have shortchanged basic legislation as well. Here are a few issues that may require the legislators to return to work: * A women's health insurance package is stalled over whether religious employers can refuse to provide medical insurance that pays for contraceptives.

headline.main: No Pay, No Work in Albany

docs.abstract: Editorial scores New York State legislators for failing to agree on budget for current fiscal year; accuses them of shortchaning other basic legislation as well (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In less than three weeks the House will reach a moment of trial for a cause that grows more urgent every day. Campaign finance reform, which was approved in April by the Senate as the McCain-Feingold bill, has already passed twice in the House, but in a different form. The version that comes up in early July has changes that some lawmakers who support the principle of reform say they do not like. Now, therefore, is the time for supporters to resolve their differences and make the fewest possible changes so that the revised bill -- sponsored by Christopher Shays of Connecticut and Martin Meehan of Massachusetts -- can win Senate approval and be sent to President Bush. If lawmakers need convincing, they need only pay attention to the fund-raising around them. Facing a tough election next year, Republicans and Democrats are working overtime to raise money, tainting what they do in Washington. This week alone, President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney will be hauling in as much as $20 million at a Republican gala.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges House members to resolve differences and make fewest possible changes so that revised campaign-finance reform bill, sponsored by Reprs Christopher Shays and Martin Meehan, can win Senate approval and be sent to Pres Bush (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HOVERING above last week's Senate debate over the so-called patients' bill of rights was an unspoken question: was all the speechmaking really just a smokescreen that obscures the truly tough health care problems facing the country? Democrats said the Republican bill would maroon patients with managed-care plans that would deny lifesaving medical procedures. Republicans countered that the Democrats were hawking a ''trial lawyers bill'' that would encourage frivolous lawsuits, driving up costs and making coverage unaffordable for millions of Americans. President Bush vowed to veto the Democratic bill.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends: Reality Check; Will Patients' Rights Fix the Wrongs?

docs.lead_paragraph: On a gray morning in Minneapolis, Tammy Hoff and Dormae Gebhardt sat in adjacent hospital beds making brave jokes with their husbands while waiting to be wheeled off to the operating room. It was a typical hospital scene, except for one detail: the two women, both in their early 30's, were perfectly healthy, and about to have major surgery that they did not need. In another bed across the room was 31-year-old Kimberly Miles, Ms. Hoff's sister and Ms. Gebhardt's friend. Thin and pale, with oxygen tubing looped about her face, Ms. Miles, too, put up a bold front, kidding with her 8-year-old son and his father.

headline.main: TRANSPLANT FRONTIERS: A special report.; Healthy Give Organs to Dying, Raising Issue of Risk and Ethics

docs.abstract: Special report, Transplant Frontiers, on ethical, emotional and medical issues arising in age of organ transplants; once unthinkable, using healthy people as organ donors to provide kidneys and portions of livers and lungs is gaining wide acceptance; there is no doubt that living donors can save lives of people who are languishing on transplant lists; but no matter how well operations go, performing major surgery on someone who does not need it still violates historical admonition that doctors must 'do no harm'; examples cited; photos; drawings (L)
